_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Executive Summary  68.155
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. is located at 1741 West Beaver Street, Duval County, Jacksonville, FL  32209.  The Beaver Street facility has over a threshold quantity of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated highly hazardous chemical per EPAA?s 40 CFR-68.  Beaver Street has a unified Risk Management Program as well as OSHA Process Safety Management program that are presented in this plan.
1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES     (a)
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68,  Prevention Program.
1.1.1.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM  (a)(1)
        Beaver Street has a management system in place which is lead by the FisheriesA? Vice President, who oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  This program, along with other facility-specific policies, eliminates and /or reduces the likelihood of an ammonia release at the facility.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plantA?s RMP Process Safety Information.
 
    
1.1.2.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3  (a)(2)
        Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  The program addresses each of the EPA Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, plus RMP elements needed to implement the program.  These are maintained in the Beaver Street plant Document Management System (DMS).  The unified PSM/RMP program was implemented in 2004 prior to increasing the maximum inventory above the 10,000 pound threshold.
1.2.    THE BEAVER STREET FISHERIES, INC. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT JACKSONVILLE, FLORIDA SITE  (b)
Beaver Street employs 225 fulltime and 132 staffing service employees e

ngaged in facility and field operations.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as part of the refrigeration process.
1.2.1.    SITE DESCRIPTION  (B)(1)
    The site is owned and operated by Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc.  The site is located at 1741 West Beaver Street, City of Jacksonville, in Duval County, Florida.  The site is located in an area, boarded by Robinson Avenue on the west, Railroad Tracks on the east, McQuade Street on the north and West Beaver Street on the south.
    The Plant includes a separate ammonia operation storage building and adjacent control room system.  The boundaries of the ammonia system subject to the RMP regulation include the Bulk Ammonia Storage and Feed Control rooms and the associated vent makeup and exhaust systems.  Ammonia is delivered to numerous refrigerator units and returns to the compressor room where it is liquefied for further use.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.
1.2.2.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE  (b)(2)
        Anhydrous Ammonia is the only regulated substance on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule 10,000 pound EPA and OSHA threshold quantity.  Beaver StreetA?s ammonia process was installed as part of the process of supplying plant refrigeration.  It operates under permit from the State of Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FL DEP).  The ammonia is stored in a receiver and distributed to the refrigerator process control systems. 
    Anhydrous ammonia is an EPA listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and it is corrosive.  AmmoniaA?s formula is NH3.  The OSHA PEL is 50 ppm.  It is flammable and is a gas at standard conditions.  Ammonia is liquefied by compression.
    
1.3.    WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS (c)
Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two ammonia release scenarios.  The first is a A?worst case releaseA?.  The second is a m

ore probable A?alternative release scenarioA?.  Results are depicted on an aerial map.  The first scenario is defined by the EPA, it states that A?the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel of a highly hazardous chemical is released as a gas over 10 minutesA? due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as A?more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarioA?.
Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the ammonia released before its concentration decreases to the A?toxic endpoint.A?  The EPA specified endpoint for ammonia is 0.14 mg/l. This endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the A?maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individualA?s ability to take protective action.A?  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, A?to estimate the population potentially affected.A?
 

1.3.1.    WORST CASE   (c)(1)
    Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions outlined in RMP-Comp.  Results demonstrate a distance of 0.9 miles to the toxic endpoint.  The residential population that could potentially be affected by the release is estimated at 7,815 people.*  There are churches, schools, residences, recreation, industrial, plus historic areas included in that release area.
1.3.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   (c)(2)
    The alternative release scenario involves the failure of a pipe or valve in the ammonia system.  This failure was defined during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating a 1/16 inch diameter hole in a pipe, valve or even a vessel.  Model

ing using the EPA/RMP Comp and EPAA?s ammonia guidance demonstrated the rate of ammonia release is 100 lb/min*.  The toxic endpoint distances determined is 0.1 miles.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is estimated at five individuals.*
    * Population counts and key receptors are recorded in the PlantA?s Process Safety information.
1.4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM  (d)
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc.A?s accidental release prevention program is based on EPAA?s RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The program has been in place and effectively used for six years.  It is part of the facilityA?s operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall plant wide program.  The second is the ammonia-specific actions within the site program.  This is coordinated with the City of Jacksonville Fire/Rescue, and Haz Mat Team as well as the Jacksonville Sheriffs Department. .
1.4.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (d)(1)
    Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:
A?    Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 
A?    The plant document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  
A?    Training and on the job experience is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphasizes awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. 
A?    Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 
A?    Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident.  We have had zero RMP reportable accidents.
A?    Employees participate in all aspects of the plant a

s listed below under emergency response. 
A?    Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out , 3) Confined Space/Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines Permit Procedure. 
A?    Contractors must meet Beaver StreetA?s high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  Plus, Beaver Street demands training of contractors to our standards. 
1.4.2.    AMMONIA-SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (d)(2)
1.4.2.1.    Ammonia-Specific Policies-Procedures
Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the ammonia specific program.  These include:
A?    Specific procedures for the operation of the ammonia process are outlined below. 
A?    Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the ammonia system.   The latest one was conducted in December, 2003 for the added equipment as part of the project expansion.
A?    Specific emergency response procedures for ammonia releases as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures. See the appendix of the Emergency Response Program book. 
A?    Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and operations level leak repair for ammonia. 
A?    Finally, the details of the facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the ammonia system.
1.4.2.2.    Facility Design
There is an ammonia storage process area:  the compressor room.  Liquefied ammonia under high pressure is supplied via a pipe network to numerous refrigeration and freezer systems.   The high pressure ammonia evaporates to a gas in the refrigeration or freezer systems.  Then this Ammonia gas is drawn back into the condensers located above the compressor room.  Here the gas is re-liquefied by the condensers and flows back to receivers and is fed to the suction side of the compressors located in the compressor room.  The liquefied ammo

nia is then drawn into the compressors and returns to the refrigeration and freezer systems.   The plant and support equipment of the ammonia compressor room and control room meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The building is equipped with ambient ventilation area.  It has a fan ventilation system, which is used during ammonia receiver charging operations.  The room is also equipped with an ammonia monitor and the system has an emergency shut down located in the adjacent control room.
1.4.2.3.    Equipment Design
There are two types of ammonia pipe systems, high pressure liquid supply lines and medium and low pressure vapor return lines.  The high pressure ammonia piping system is made of ammonia compatible steel pipes or equipment.  These materials are steel or ammonia compatible non-metallic compound (not corroded by ammonia) rated to 2,500 psig.  The typical pressure of the ammonia in the high pressure system is only 150 psig giving a substantive safety factor.  This system is extensive, leading from the ammonia compressor room to each of the individual refrigerator or freezer units.  
The medium and low pressure system operates under a positive pressure.  All the pipe, tubes, and equipment are also ammonia compatible.  Ammonia from the freezers returns at six psig and ammonia from the refrigeration units retunes at 20 psig.  The high pressure system is designed using schedule 80 seamless pipe and fittings designed 2,500 psig giving it a large safety factor over the typical positive pressure in the high pressure system. The low pressure system  uses schedule 40 pipe and fittings and is rated from 450 to 1.000 psig.  The low pressure system operates at 6 psig for freezer return lines and 20 psig for refrigeration return lines. There is an ammonia monitor which detects the presence of ammonia in the compressor room storage area.  
1.5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY  (e)
There have been zero EPA recorded accidents in the past five year

s.    

1.6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  (f)
Emergency response procedures contain the Plant Emergency Response Policy and are coordinated with the City of Jacksonville (Emergency Response Plan) and the LEPC.  The plan includes an emergency response A?decision treeA? and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site specific emergency actions defined in the plants operating procedures.  Emergency response drills and drill evacuations are conducted by the operating department.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.
The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the Plant Wide Safety Committee, the Jacksonville Department (who man the nearby City Fire/Rescue Station).  The plant coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the City of Jacksonville Fire Department HazMat team.  All are located in Duval County, Florida.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, management, and police departments in the City of Jacksonville and Duval County.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the Beaver Street plant.
The Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to an ammonia spill (release).  The plan includes training of all ammonia-area operators.  The primary response team includes the Jacksonville Fire and Rescue, plus the Haz Mat Team.  All of these respond to severe ammonia leak situations.  Actions include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  Public notification is facilitated through the City of Jacksonville Fire Rescue, Police and Duval County Emergency Management Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.
1.6.1.    PERSONNEL  (f)(1)
    Personnel are the key resource of the Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. prevention program. Plant employees make up the operators and emergency res

ponse teams.  Beaver Street fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the ammonia system operation.
A?    RMP safety teams, 
A?    Development of the operation procedures, 
A?    Hazard evaluations and Process Hazards Analysis 
A?    On-going training of the operators and other ammonia involved staff.

1.7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (g)
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the recent internal safety, tour, and audit of the RMP program to meet requirements of the Risk Management Prevention Program.  These recommended actions have now been evaluated and implemented as required.  A Process Hazard Analysis was conducted in December, 2009 to review the RMP program.  The key safety action items were completed including resubmission of the RMP e*Submit to the EPA.  See the A?UpdateA? Section 6 of this report.
Beaver Street Fisheries, inc. continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, Beaver Street management team and process safety team are reviewing potential to the existing design of the ammonia operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of ammonia.
